0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection, Nasal colonization: intranasal ointment, apply one-half of single-use 1 g tube into each nostril TOPICALLY twice daily for 5 days
  • Secondary infection - Skin lesion: apply 2% cream TOPICALLY 3 times per day for 10 days

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection, Nasal colonization: (12 years of age and older) intranasal ointment, apply one-half of single-use 1 g tube into each nostril TOPICALLY twice daily for 5 days
  • Secondary infection - Skin lesion: (3 months and older) apply 2% cream TOPICALLY 3 times per day for 10 days

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection, Nasal colonization
  • Secondary infection - Skin lesion
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Superficial bacterial infection of skin

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Hypersensitivity to mupirocin calcium or to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Dermatologic:
  • -- Systemic allergic reactions, including urticaria and generalized rash, have been reported
  • -- Discontinue use if sensitization or severe local irritation occur
  • Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea has been reported, including cases occurring more than 2 months after administration; evaluate and institute appropriate medical management if suspected or confirmed; discontinuation may be warranted
  • -- Cream not recommended for use on mucosal surfaces
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Systemic allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, have been reported
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Avoid contact with eyes and rinse thoroughly if accidental contact occurs
  • -- Overgrowth of nonsusceptible organisms, including fungi, may occur with prolonged therapy
  • Other:
  • -- Systemic allergic reactions, including angioedema, have been reported
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid use of mupirocin nasal ointment with other intranasal products

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Mupirocin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (1% nasal ointment; 2.4% cream), Rash (1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (1.1% to 4.9% cream; less than 1% nasal ointment)
  • Neurologic:Headache (1.7% to 3.6% cream; 9% nasal ointment)
  • Respiratory:Disorder of respiratory system (5% nasal ointment), Pharyngitis (4% nasal ointment), Rhinitis (6% nasal ointment)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Nasal
    • apply morning and evenings
    • after application, press nostrils together and release repeatedly for 1 minute to spread ointment throughout the nares
    • discard tube after use; do not re-use
    • do not use concurrently with any other intranasal products
  • Topical
    • may cover treated areas with gauze dressings if desired
    • avoid contact with eyes

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• clearing of infected skin (topical cream).
  • Eradication of colonization (nasal ointment)
  • re-evaluate patients who have not shown a clinical response within 3 to 5 days of starting therapy (topical cream).
  • evidence of sensitization or severe local irritation.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including up to 2 months after therapy.
  • Direct patient to report symptoms of sensitization or severe local irritation.
  • Intranasal side effects may include headaches, rhinitis, upper respiratory tract congestion, pharyngitis, taste perversion, burning, stinging, cough, or pruritus.
  • Topical side effects may include burning, cellulitis, pruritus, rash, or nausea.
  • Tell patient to keep drug away from the eyes; if this occurs, rinse eyes with water.
